title: Login CSRF vulnerability on hackerone.com

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
###Summary
Hi. We found a CSRF token bypass on the Hacker One login page.
So, this report describes Hacker One login CSRF Token Bypass.

###Exploitation process
Hacker One uses the authenticity_token token during login to prevent CSRF.
However, the authenticity_token token is not properly verified, so an attacker can log in via CSRF without the authenticity_token token.
In other words, Hacker One thinks that it implemented CSRF token through authenticity_token token, but it is not.

###Steps To Reproduce
1. Go to `https://hackerone.com/users/sign_in`
2. While logging into your account, grab packets through the buff suit.
3. Take the HTML code format from burp suite -> Engagement Tools -> Generate CSRF POC.
4. Delete the authenticity token.
5. Forward the request and CSRF exploited successfully and the modified data changed successfully :)

###PoC
```javascript
<html>
  <!-- CSRF PoC - generated by Burp Suite Professional -->
  <body>
  <script>history.pushState('', '', '/')</script>
    <form action="https://hackerone.com/users/sign_in" method="POST">
      <input type="hidden" name="user[email]" value="youremail" />
      <input type="hidden" name="user[password]" value="yourpassword" />
      <input type="hidden" name="user[remember_me]" value="1" />
      <input type="submit" value="Submit request" />
    </form>
  </body>
</html>
```

## Impact

The victim may add sensitive payment information to the attacker's new account 
{F765737}

the victim's IP may be recorded in the attacker's account, resulting in brute force and identity theft.
█████

activities.message:
Hi @what_web, 

Thank you for your submission! I got the following response using the above CSRF login form with valid email and password. 

```
HTTP/1.1 412 Precondition Failed
Date: Mon, 30 Mar 2020 18:20:29 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
Connection: close
Set-Cookie: █████████
X-Request-Id: bf93643a-bcd1-4cf2-949c-9b46dd160cc0
Cache-Control: no-cache
Set-Cookie: █████████
Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains; preload
X-Frame-Options: DENY
X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block
X-Download-Options: noopen
X-Permitted-Cross-Domain-Policies: none
Referrer-Policy: strict-origin-when-cross-origin
Expect-CT: enforce, max-age=86400
Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'none'; base-uri 'self'; block-all-mixed-content; child-src www.youtube-nocookie.com; connect-src 'self' www.google-analytics.com errors.hackerone.net; font-src 'self'; form-action 'self'; frame-ancestors 'none'; img-src 'self' data: cover-photos.hackerone-user-content.com hackathon-photos.hackerone-user-content.com profile-photos.hackerone-user-content.com hackerone-us-west-2-production-attachments.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com; media-src 'self' hackerone-us-west-2-production-attachments.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com; script-src 'self' www.google-analytics.com; style-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline'; report-uri https://errors.hackerone.net/api/30/csp-report/?sentry_key=61c1e2f50d21487c97a071737701f598
CF-Cache-Status: DYNAMIC
Server: cloudflare
CF-RAY: 57c3d83dfc76d5b3-BOM
Content-Length: 1169
```

I tested again in Firefox and Chrome, and but I was able to reproduce it successfully. and If you log in with a valid ID as you say, 412 responses are reflected. However, if I check my current status through refresh, the login is already successful. I prepared a video for proof of concept.
██████████
Thank you hackerone best security Analyst !
Best Dear
@what_web

Hello Hacker One team.
Thank you for resolving your login CSRF problem quickly. But unfortunately this problem is still reproducible.

###Diagnostic process
I tested this problem again. Initially it was designed to implement logins via `authenticity` tokens via `https://hackerone.com/users/sign_in` URL, but now testing again, we now have a problem to implement logins via `fingerprint` token via `hackerone.com/sessions` URL I solved it again and solved the CSRF problem of the login page. But, unfortunately, still working on my PoC, `https://hackerone.com/users/sign_in`, and CSRF works successfully if I log in with existing `login parameters`.

Old code
```javascript
https://hackerone.com/users/sign_in
      <input type="hidden" name="user[email]" value="youremail" />
      <input type="hidden" name="user[password]" value="yourpassword" />
      <input type="hidden" name="user[remember_me]" value="1" />
```

New code
```javascript
https://hackerone.com/sessions
      <input type="hidden" name="email" value="youremail" />
      <input type="hidden" name="password" value="yourpassword" />
      <input type="hidden" name="remember_me" value="false" />
```

In other words, the current hackerone solved the problem by modifying the Token on the login page, the parameter that receives the login, and the current URL as sessions, but the cause can still be reproduced through the existing PoC.

Best regards.
@what_web

Hi @what_web, 

Thank you for the additional information! To make it clear, we did not push any changes, we have both the endpoints used for the login purpose, I'm going to check with the team if "Login CSRF" represent any security risk or not, will keep you updated.

Hi @what_web - thanks again for your report. We'll escalate this to our engineering team. We are able to reproduce the behavior you describe and will determine if this is something we'd like to fix next week. Thanks!

Hi @what_web, 

As said in the last comment, the internal team still need to confirm if this is something we would like to address or not, we will keep you updated once we have more information to share.

@what_web Apologies for the delay on this particular issue, doesn't happen that often. This hasn't been at the top of our list because it's rather tricky to exploit it (although not impossible). I'll assign it to myself and figure out where this CSRF-like behavior comes from. Thanks again for your patience!

PS Lovely picture!
Thank you.

Hi @what_web - I've looked into this and I was able to reproduce it! For some reason, your initial proof of concept didn't work for me, both on my local development environment or production. Your video was great because it showed that it was definitely working at some point, so I dived into the code until I figured out what was happening. We'll get a fix out for this. I suspect that this will go out next week. Thanks!

Hi @jobert Thank you for coming back.
I am really happy. Thank you very much :)
Thanks again, @what_web!

Hi @jobert I do not agree that the severity of this report is 3.8. This is a severity level between 4.0 and 4.2, and I think you guys made a mistake when measuring the severity.

You seem to have measured the severity by looking only at the login CSRF issue, but this report also included a CSRF token bypass issue. At the time of my test, a CSRF token was issued at the time of login and attempted to log in, but the CSRF token was not valid, so it was possible to bypass the login without the CSRF token.

Anyway, I was happy to work with you. Can I redefine the severity?

Regards,
-JaeHak

> The report included a Token bypass issue, not just a login CSRF issue.

That's not the case. You won't be able to use this to bypass the CSRF protection on any other endpoint. Feel free to try, but you'll notice that it won't work. Because of that, we're keeping the severity set to 3.8. We'll provide a detailed write-up how this could've happened, which will also be proof that this only applied to the login page.

Hi @jobert 

Could the severity change during the investigation of this report?

Regards 
-JaeHak

**TL;DR**: a specially crafted HTTP request could be send to the `/users/sign_in` endpoint that threw an exception, returning an authenticated session cookie when valid credentials were provided. This leads to a login CSRF vulnerability.

Hi @what_web - sure, if we would've uncovered any new information that would've bumped up the severity, we would reflect that in the report. However, that's not the case. This is truly only a CSRF vulnerability for the login page. Technical details and root cause analysis:

In HackerOne's `ApplicationController`, a number of hooks are defined that invoke the `current_user` method, for example when setting the [user context for Raven](https://docs.sentry.io/clients/ruby/context/) or configuring additional logging context for HackerOne's log aggregation platform — more about this later.

The `current_user` method is meta-programmed as a helper by Devise v4.7.1, the authentication library HackerOne uses. It is implemented [as such](https://github.com/heartcombo/devise/blob/v4.7.1/lib/devise/controllers/helpers.rb#L125):

```
#...
def current_#{mapping}
  @current_#{mapping} ||= warden.authenticate(scope: :#{mapping})
end
#...
```

The first time the method is called, the `warden.authenticate` method will be called. This will go through the Devise authentication strategies and will determine if the user can authenticate with the given credentials (e.g. a SAML header, username/password/OTP combination, etc.). When looping over the strategies, the `valid?` method is called on each authentication strategy. This behavior can be seen in the `Warden::Proxy` class ([link](https://github.com/wardencommunity/warden/blob/v1.2.8/lib/warden/proxy.rb#L367)).

One of HackerOne's authentication strategies inherits from Devise's `Authenticatable` class. The [`valid?`](https://github.com/heartcombo/devise/blob/v4.7.1/lib/devise/strategies/authenticatable.rb#L18) method for this strategy determines two things: whether valid authentication parameters are present or if an HTTP authentication header is present (e.g. for APIs):

```ruby
# ...
module Devise
  module Strategies
    # ...

    class Authenticatable < Base
      # ...

      def valid?
        valid_for_params_auth? || valid_for_http_auth?
      end

      # ...

      def valid_for_params_auth?
        params_authenticatable? && valid_params_request? &&
          valid_params? && with_authentication_hash(:params_auth, params_auth_hash)
      end

      # ...

      def valid_params_request?
        !!env["devise.allow_params_authentication"]
      end

      # ...
```

As can be seen in the code above, it'll require the Warden environment variable `devise.allow_params_authentication` to contain a truthy value for it to return `true` for the `valid?` method. This environment variable is set to `false` by default. There is one code path that sets this variable to true: the `Users::SessionsController#create` action. This controller is inherited from `Devise::SessionsController`. This base class configures a number of actions that need to run before certain requests:

```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

class Devise::SessionsController < DeviseController
  prepend_before_action :require_no_authentication, only: [:new, :create]
  prepend_before_action :allow_params_authentication!, only: :create
  prepend_before_action :verify_signed_out_user, only: :destroy
  prepend_before_action(only: [:create, :destroy]) { request.env["devise.skip_timeout"] = true }

  # ...
end
```

The `allow_params_authentication!` method [is implemented as following](https://github.com/heartcombo/devise/blob/v4.7.1/lib/devise/controllers/helpers.rb#L164):

```ruby
def allow_params_authentication!
  request.env["devise.allow_params_authentication"] = true
end
```

Because execution of the `allow_params_authentication!` is prepended, it'll run this code before any other `before_action` hook defined in HackerOne's `ApplicationController` — including before the CSRF protection. This means that even before the controller action is invoked, it can authenticate a user and `current_user` can return a `User` object. We never noticed that this was a problem because the `set-cookie` header is **not** returned for 4xx HTTP responses, which is returned to the user when an invalid CSRF token is provided. However, it is possible to trigger a 5xx HTTP response, which **does** return the header, which may reveal a new session cookie and store it in the browser. The session cookie is returned because HackerOne mutates the Rails session store for its session replay mitigation. Irony: if we wouldn't have session replay mitigation in place, we wouldn't need to mutate the session, which would prevent the `set-cookie` header to be returned.

In HackerOne's `ApplicationController`, CSRF protection is configured with the following code:

```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

class ApplicationController < ActionController::Base
  # ...

  protect_from_forgery with: :exception, prepend: true

  # ...

  def form_authenticity_param
    params.permit(request_forgery_protection_token => Parameters.string)
    super
  end

  # ...
end
```

The code above shows that the application expects a `String` to provided for the `authenticity_token` header. When it is provided any other type, `StrongerParameters` will raise an exception, which will lead to a 5xx HTTP response.

Every request that is processed by our backend is logged. HackerOne uses the `lograge` gem to export log entries as JSON. Each request is tagged with an additional payload, adding context and metadata for debugging and incident response. For that, HackerOne leverages the `append_info_to_payload ` method. This method is called automatically as part of the default Rails instrumentation here: https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/40b7d93c5bf04974cfd0201a8e391c499c046f0b/actionpack/lib/action_controller/metal/instrumentation.rb#L39. The implementation of HackerOne's method looks like this:

```ruby
def append_info_to_payload(payload)
  super

  payload.merge! additional_logging_context
end

# ...

def additional_logging_context
  truncated_user_agent = (request.user_agent || '')[0..254]
  {
    ip: request.ip,
    user_agent: truncated_user_agent,
    request_id: request.request_id,
    host: request.host,
    port: request.port,
    session: {
      user_id: current_user&.id,
      username: current_user&.username,
      user_session_id: current_session&.id,
      hackerone_employee: current_user&.hackerone_employee,
      hackerone_triager: current_user&.hackerone_triager,
      cfduid: request.cookies[CLOUDFLARE_ID],
      ip_country: request.headers[CLOUDFLARE_COUNTRY],
    },
    controller: controller_name,
    action: action_name,
    custom: {},
  }
end
```

As can be seen, `current_user` is called a number of times, which unknowingly authenticates the user when an exception is thrown when trying to call the `Users::SessionsController#create` action. Below are two HTTP requests showing the minor difference between an invalid CSRF token and passing a non-String value as CSRF token:

**Invalid CSRF**
*Request*
```
POST /users/sign_in HTTP/1.1
Host: hackerone.com

user[email]=hello@world.com&user[password]=example&authenticity_token=invalid
```

*Response*
```
HTTP/1.1 412 Precondition Failed
...
```

**Invalid object type**
*Request*
```
POST /users/sign_in HTTP/1.1
Host: hackerone.com

user[email]=hello@world.com&user[password]=example&authenticity_token[]=invalid
                                                                     ^ -- Array
```

*Response*
```
HTTP/1.1 500 Internal Server Error
Set-Cookie: session=<session cookie>
...
```

In the end, the following proof of concept could be used to consistently sign in a user without a valid CSRF token:

```
<html>
  <body>
  <script>history.pushState('', '', '/')</script>
    <form action="https://hackerone.com/users/sign_in" method="POST">
      <input type="hidden" name="user[email]" value="hello@world.com" />
      <input type="hidden" name="user[password]" value="example" />
      <input type="hidden" name="authenticity_token[]" value="invalid" />
      <input type="submit" value="Submit request" />
    </form>
  </body>
</html>
```

We put up a fix for the vulnerability earlier today and is being reviewed. Once this has been merged and deployed, the fix will be posted here as well.

Thanks again, @what_web, this turned out to be a fun bug to do a root cause analysis on!

Hi @jobert
You are a very accurate and great investigation! As I said before, this is a wide range of other issues, so I'm discussing the severity. In fact, I didn't find much more than you found, but I knew this could be a wide range of other potential problems, but I just stayed silent because I couldn't provide any additional practical proof of concept.

Can you re-examine the severity of this report?

I am so happy to work with you!

The results you showed me during your research are really interesting and really great. Thanks again for the great findings. ! 

Regards
-jaeHak

Hi @what_web - like I said earlier, given the impact of the vulnerability we're keeping the severity set to 3.8. This decision is final.

We came up with the following fix, which was released a few minutes ago. A copy can be found in F846791.

```
diff --git a/app/controllers/application_controller.rb b/app/controllers/application_controller.rb
index 8800599ab8..5a12cc237a 100644
--- a/app/controllers/application_controller.rb
+++ b/app/controllers/application_controller.rb
@@ -23,7 +23,6 @@ class ApplicationController < ActionController::Base
 
   before_action(
     :authenticate_user!,
-    :whitelisted_cidr_range,
     :only_allow_active_accounts,
     :required_mfa?,
     :form_authenticity_token,
@@ -233,14 +232,6 @@ class ApplicationController < ActionController::Base
     ProtectedAttribute::SchemaUtility.ensure_public_schema
   end
 
-  def whitelisted_cidr_range
-    return unless current_user && !current_user.whitelisted_ip_address?(request.remote_ip)
-
-    sign_out_and_redirect(current_user)
-
-    flash[:error] = 'You cannot sign in from this IP address.'
-  end
-
   def required_mfa?
     return unless Commands::Users::RedirectIfTwoFactorAuthRequired.interact(
       request_path: request.path,
@@ -285,4 +276,10 @@ class ApplicationController < ActionController::Base
   def support_app?
     ENV['SUPPORT_APPLICATION'].present?
   end
+
+  def enable_parameter_authentication
+    warden.env["devise.allow_params_authentication"] = true
+    yield
+    warden.env["devise.allow_params_authentication"] = false
+  end
 end
diff --git a/app/controllers/saml/sessions_controller.rb b/app/controllers/saml/sessions_controller.rb
index 1ff1b61bb5..b61ba72b91 100644
--- a/app/controllers/saml/sessions_controller.rb
+++ b/app/controllers/saml/sessions_controller.rb
@@ -29,6 +29,8 @@ module Saml
   class SessionsController < Devise::SessionsController
     unloadable if Rails::VERSION::MAJOR < 4
 
+    skip_before_action :allow_params_authentication!
+
     prepend_before_action :require_no_authentication, only: [:unconfirmed, :metadata]
     prepend_before_action :verify_saml_response_test!, only: :create
 
@@ -36,6 +38,8 @@ module Saml
 
     after_action :set_or_remove_marketing_site_cookie, only: [:create]
 
+    around_action :enable_parameter_authentication, only: :create
+
     def new
       if saml_request.valid?
         saml_request.try(:saml_test)&.start!
diff --git a/app/controllers/users/sessions_controller.rb b/app/controllers/users/sessions_controller.rb
index 851a01e250..a114176cac 100644
--- a/app/controllers/users/sessions_controller.rb
+++ b/app/controllers/users/sessions_controller.rb
@@ -2,11 +2,15 @@
 
 module Users
   class SessionsController < Devise::SessionsController
+    skip_before_action :allow_params_authentication!
+
     before_action :set_invitation, only: [:create, :new]
-    before_action :set_user_ip_country, only: [:create]
+    after_action :set_user_ip_country, only: [:create]
     after_action :set_or_remove_marketing_site_cookie, only: [:create, :destroy]
     after_action :clear_browser_cache, only: :destroy
 
+    around_action :enable_parameter_authentication, only: :create
+
     def new
       respond_to do |format|
         format.html do
@@ -25,10 +29,6 @@ module Users
       use_content_security_policy_named_append(:zendesk)
     end
 
-    def create
-      super
-    end
-
     private
 
     def set_user_ip_country
diff --git a/config/initializers/devise_disable_param_authentication.rb b/config/initializers/devise_disable_param_authentication.rb
new file mode 100644
index 0000000000..99cb31b482
--- /dev/null
+++ b/config/initializers/devise_disable_param_authentication.rb
@@ -0,0 +1,13 @@
+# frozen_string_literal: true
+
+module Devise
+  module Controllers
+    module Helpers
+      def allow_params_authentication!
+        fail SecurityError, 'The use of this method may introduce login CSRF ' \
+          'vulnerabilities when `current_user` is called after this method is ' \
+          'invoked. Its usage is disabled. See #39517 for more information.'
+      end
+    end
+  end
+end
diff --git a/config/locales/devise.en.yml b/config/locales/devise.en.yml
index 0ded2d0349..d0cc97ed6a 100644
--- a/config/locales/devise.en.yml
+++ b/config/locales/devise.en.yml
@@ -21,6 +21,7 @@ en:
       unconfirmed: "Your account has been successfully created. Please check your email inbox to confirm your address."
       user:
         session_conflict: "You've been signed out due to a session conflict. Please sign in again."
+        blocked_ip: "You cannot sign in from this IP address."
     mailer:
       confirmation_instructions:
         subject: "Please confirm your email address with HackerOne"
diff --git a/lib/hackerone/user_authentication/authentication_callback.rb b/lib/hackerone/user_authentication/authentication_callback.rb
index 0b6e18177c..aaf67cb354 100644
--- a/lib/hackerone/user_authentication/authentication_callback.rb
+++ b/lib/hackerone/user_authentication/authentication_callback.rb
@@ -26,6 +26,11 @@ module UserAuthentication
             throw :warden, message: :timeout
           end
 
+          unless session.user.whitelisted_ip_address?(request.remote_ip)
+            request.env['warden'].reset_session!
+            throw :warden, message: :blocked_ip
+          end
+
           if session.user.limit_session_to_one_ip_address? &&
               session.ip_address != request.ip
             Rails.logger.warn \
diff --git a/spec/integration/controllers/users/sessions_controller_spec.rb b/spec/integration/controllers/users/sessions_controller_spec.rb
index de617fe8c1..abd2e79b4e 100644
--- a/spec/integration/controllers/users/sessions_controller_spec.rb
+++ b/spec/integration/controllers/users/sessions_controller_spec.rb
@@ -79,14 +79,6 @@ describe Users::SessionsController do
       expect(last_user_session.session_token).not_to be_nil
     end
 
-    it 'sets the user id in the raven context after logging in' do
-      expect(Raven).to receive(:user_context)
-        .with(id: user.id, username: user.username)
-        .exactly(3)
-        .times
-      post :create, params: { user: { email: email, password: pass } }
-    end
-
     context 'CloudFlare IP Country header' do
       it 'sets both country fields' do
         request.headers['CF-IPCountry'] = 'US'
@@ -119,6 +111,27 @@ describe Users::SessionsController do
       end
     end
 
+    # Regression spec for #39517
+    context 'with array as authentication token' do
+      let(:pass) { '███████' }
+      let(:user) { create :user, password: pass }
+
+      before { ActionController::Base.allow_forgery_protection = true }
+      after { ActionController::Base.allow_forgery_protection = false }
+
+      it do
+        expect do
+          post :create, params: {
+            authenticity_token: ['this-is-an-array'],
+              user: {
+                email: user.email,
+                password: pass,
+              },
+          }
+        end.not_to change { user.reload.user_sessions.count }
+      end
+    end
+
     context 'Intercom', intercom: :send do
       let(:queue) { Interactors::Intercom::CreateUserAndTeam.jobs }
```

There are two notable changes: first, we've disabled the use of the `allow_params_authentication!` method used by Devise. Going forward, it'll raise a security warning when it is being used. Second, we've replaced it with a method that wraps around the two actions that sign a user in: `users/sessions#create` and `saml/sessions#create`. We believe that this is a sufficient fix for the reported security vulnerability.

We decided not to open a pull request with Devise for now because there are legitimate use cases for the `allow_params_authentication!`. This security vulnerability was introduced because of our own implementation.

The following test plan should help determine if the security vulnerability was address:

1. Submit the following HTTP request with valid credentials

```
POST /users/sign_in HTTP/1.1
Host: hackerone.com
...

user[email]=:email&user[password]=:password&authenticity_token[]=this-is-an-array
```

2. Expect a response with a `set-cookie` header

```
HTTP/1.1 400 Bad Request
set-cookie: session=:session; path=/; expires=Thu, 11 Jun 2020 19:05:39 GMT; HttpOnly
...

Invalid parameter: authenticity_token must be a string
```

3. Submit an HTTP request to `/current_user.json` with the created session

```
GET /current_user.json HTTP/1.1
Cookie: session=:session;
...
```

4. Expect the response to indicate the session isn't authenticated

```
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
...

{"csrf_token":":token","signed_in?":false,"is_member_of_teams":false}
```

additional_data.old_title: [www.hackerone.com] Attackers can bypass authenticity CSRF tokens during login.

activities.message: Hi @what_web - thanks! For the `/current_user.json` request, can you use a `GET` request instead of a `POST` request? The endpoint only implements a `GET` request.

I was a high school student, so I couldn't reply because I was in school. I tried GET POST all but failed to attach a picture.
I could not reproduce everything.

Thank you !
I will definitely attach the requested photo after testing again as soon as I get home after school.
@jobert
Thanks for retesting, @what_web, it's much appreciated!

Hi @what_web - thanks, but as per our policy, all confirmed and resolved security vulnerabilities are publicly disclosed:

> We believe in transparency about our security, so any valid vulnerabilities discovered are always publicly disclosed once confirmed and resolved.

Can you help me understand what you're worried about? I'm happy to redact any potentially sensitive information that you don't want to be disclosed. Thanks!

Hi @what_web -

> Also included in this report is the authenticity_token bypass

Like I explained earlier in the report, this isn't an authenticity token bypass. The impact of the vulnerability is limited to a login CSRF and could not have been used to execute any other action on hackerone.com. We will keep the title the same. Thanks!
